page.title: 18BARBER'S BRIDGE, RUDFORD
page.content: Barber's Bridge is notable for two features and is frequently visited by sightseers and historians. An obelisk built from stones from Gloucester's medieval walls was erected after the discovery in 1868 of 86 skeletons believed to be those of Welsh soldiers who fell in 1643, following the Battle of Highnam, while fighting for Charles I's Royalist Army. Nearby, the earthworks of the Gloucester_Ledbury Canal are clearly visible. This was constructed in 1798 to transport coal, and was extended to Hereford in 1845. In 1887, the Great Western Railway Line was built from Gloucester-Ledbury along its length; this closed in 1964. Although now both dwelling houses, the stationmaster's house and the station itself at Barbers Bridge have been carefully preserved architecturally.
